ResourceHeader.Description: Double Star 1 (also known as Tan Ce 1, and TC 1) is a Sino-European (CSNA-ESA) satellite that was launched by a Long March 2C/SM rocket from Xichang Satellite Launch Center in the Sichuan province of China (PRC) at 19:06 UT on 29 December 2003. The 330 kg, 260 W satellite is cylindrical, with a diameter of 2.1 m, a height of 1.4 m, and spins at a rate of 15 rpm. It carries eight instruments to probe Earth's magnetosphere, five from ESA and three from CNSA. (The ESA instruments are legacies from ESA's Cluster mission.) The data from all instruments will be stored on-board and dumped over three grounds stations: Shanghai and Beijing in China, and Villafranca in Spain. There will be coordination between the Cluster and Double Star missions.

ResourceHeader.Description: PEACE (Plasma Electron And Current Experiment) infers the positive potential of the spacecraft by counting the number and speed of the thermal electrons that impinge on it. This measurement is an input to the operation of ASPOC.

InformationURL.Name: NSSDC's Master Catalog
InformationURL.Description: Information about the PEACE (Plasma Electron And Current Experiment) experiment on the Double Star 1 mission.

Instrument.InvestigationName: PEACE (Plasma Electron And Current Experiment) on Double Star 1

ResourceHeader.Description: FGM (Flux Gate Magnetometer) is located on a 3.5 meter long boom and measures the magnetic field along the orbit at a rate up to 67 samples per second.

InformationURL.Name: NSSDC's Master Catalog
InformationURL.Description: Information about the FGM (Flux Gate Magnetometer) experiment on the Double Star 1 mission.

Instrument.InvestigationName: FGM (Flux Gate Magnetometer) on Double Star 1

InformationURL.Name: Double Star 1 Orbit Information
InformationURL.Description: Introduction to the Double Star 1 Orbit.

ResourceHeader.Description: ASPOC (Active Space Potential Control) is to maintain the potential of the spacecraft at a low voltage. The tendency to attain high positive voltage due mainly to photoelectron emission is sought to be neutralized by shooting out positive indium ions. The spacecraft potential is continuously monitored by the PEACE instrument.

InformationURL.Name: NSSDC's Master Catalog
InformationURL.Description: Information about the ASPOC (Active Space Potential Control) experiment on the Double Star 1 mission.

Instrument.InvestigationName: ASPOC (Active Space Potential Control) on Double Star 1

ResourceHeader.Description: HEED (High Energy Electron Detector) measures the flux of energetic electrons in the magnetosphere.

InformationURL.Name: NSSDC's Master Catalog
InformationURL.Description: Information about the HEED (High Energy Electron Detector) experiment on the Double Star 1 mission.

Instrument.InvestigationName: HEED (High Energy Electron Detector) on Double Star 1

ResourceHeader.Description: HIA (Hot Ion Analyzer) meausres the distribution function of ions in the magnetosphere and the solar wind, during each spin period of four seconds.

InformationURL.Name: NSSDC's Master Catalog
InformationURL.Description: Information about the HIA (Hot Ion Analyzer) experiment on the Double Star 1 mission.

Instrument.InvestigationName: HIA (Hot Ion Analyzer) on Double Star 1

ResourceHeader.Description: HID (Heavy Ion Detector) detects heavy ions of AMU>4.

InformationURL.Name: NSSDC's Master Catalog
InformationURL.Description: Information about the HID (Heavy Ion Detector) experiment on the Double Star 1 mission.

Instrument.InvestigationName: HID (Heavy Ion Detector) on Double Star 1

ResourceHeader.Description: HEPD (High Energy Proton Detector) detects energetic protons in the magnetosphere and solar wind.

InformationURL.Name: NSSDC's Master Catalog
InformationURL.Description: Information about the HEPD (High Energy Proton Detector) experiment on the Double Star 1 mission.

Instrument.InvestigationName: HEPD (High Energy Proton Detector) on Double Star 1

ResourceHeader.ResourceName: STAFF-DWP (Spatio-Temporal Analyzer of Field Fluctuations and Digital Wave Processor
ResourceHeader.Description: STAFF-DWP (Spatio-Temporal Analyzer of Field Fluctuations and Digital Wave Processor) The data from the magnetometer consists of two components. The low frequency components are transmitted to the ground for analysis. The higher frequency components are best analyzed on-board by a DWP and STAFF and the result telemetered to the ground stations.

InformationURL.Name: NSSDC's Master Catalog
InformationURL.Description: Information about the STAFF-DWP (Spatio-Temporal Analyzer of Field Fluctuations and Digital Wave Processor experiment on the Double Star 1 mission.

Instrument.InvestigationName: STAFF-DWP (Spatio-Temporal Analyzer of Field Fluctuations and Digital Wave Processor on Double Star 1
